newsitem.title: USA: Bill Cosby expected to testify in NY trial.
newsitem.headline: Bill Cosby expected to testify in NY trial.

text.p: Entertainer Bill Cosby was expected to testify on Tuesday in the trial of a woman charged with trying to extort $40 million from him in return for not telling a newspaper that she is his illegitimate daughter.
People started lining up outside the U.S. District Court in Manhattan at 6 a.m. EDT (1100 GMT) for the 25 to 30 seats available to the general public for Cosby's appearance.
Cosby has admitted to having had an affair with the mother of 22-year-old Autumn Jackson, but denied being Jackson's father. Paternity is not an issue in the trial.

Tape recordings played at the trial on Monday revealed that Cosby's attorney Jack Schmitt agreed to pay Jackson $24 million not to tell a supermarket tabloid newspaper that she was his illegitimate daughter.
Jackson was arrested in January. She and her alleged accomplices, Jose Medina, 51, and Boris Sabas, were charged with conspiracy, extortion and engaging in interstate commerce to commit crimes.
If convicted they could face prison terms of 12 years and fines of $750,000.
When the trial began last week, the government introduced a Jan. 16 letter Jackson wrote to former CBS President Peter Lund.

In the letter Jackson said she wanted to speak to Lund and Cosby about her "undeserved and impoverished financial and living conditions" or she would expose the entertainer in a move that could hurt the ratings of his current CBS television programme.
She said if Lund and Cosby could not help her, she would sell her story to the Globe supermarket tabloid. She enclosed a contract with the Globe for $25,000.
